name: Oster Cordless Electric Wine Bottle Opener with Foil Cutter, FFP, One, Silver
about_this_item: Cordless electric bottle opener removes the cork in seconds
Opens upto 30 bottles on a single charge(6 8 hours); Simple push button operation
Foil cutter for easily removing seals; Comfortable soft grip handle
Sleek, sophisticated design; Recharging base included; UL approved for 110-120 voltage

title: Verified Purchase
content: This is an item that sits on our counter since it is used several times a week and you must keep it charged. There were many brands to choose from—I chose Oster since it has been around for a long time and also because the price was right. I see one problem—after charging it for the first time, overnight to be sure, the red light was still on. So was there a problem? I went to the written info to find out that it stays red. It would have been better if they had used a different color since we have been programmed to think red means stop, not ready, don’t proceed, or trouble.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2024

title: My favorite appliance in the kitchen
content: I'm almost embarrassed to say I lived almost 28 years before owning this electric wine opener. Wow. What a game changer. Life is hard enough, you should not have to break a sweat to enjoy a glass (or 4) of wine. Am I right? I love it so much, it is now the only gift I give. Getting married? You're getting an electric wine opener. Baby shower? You're definitely getting an electric wine opener. It is honestly my favorite appliance in the kitchen. It has earned the coveted permanent spot on the counter. (You know how you have a closet full of crockpots but would never dream of actually storing them on the kitchen counter? Not this little treasure. Nope. Always on the counter.)
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2021

title: Eas.y to use, works well
content: This wine bottle opener works well and is easy to use. I've had several, and they last about two years. I don't want to use any other type of opener. I replace them when they fail, they aren't expensive. But now I'm having a new problem! Could be the sea air here in Hawaii. The black material on it is deteriorating. When I used it, my fingers came away with a heavy black coating that doesn't wash off. I had to use a scratcher sponge to scour off the black rubber coating on my fingers! I have wrapped it in a paper towel, so I don't have to touch it! I bought it in September of '21, so I've used it 15-16 months. It's now Jan '23. My friends won't use it. They dig in a drawer for a cork screw.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: I really liked this opener. It worked really well and looked pretty sleek. I'm in the unique position where I've purchased quite of few of these as gifts for family members and two for myself (my family loves wine). Why two for myself? Well, as it gets older the batter stops holding a charge quite like it used to and we had one run out battery with a cork in it. I'm sure that you're sitting there thinking "LopsidedMidget, don't be a dummy. Just recharge it and *poof* you are absolved of your issue." This would be true.. with nearly any other brand. However, Oster charges by sitting on the stand and a cork gets in the way of that happening. You either have to take the whole thing apart, or invest in a new opener once this happens to you. Of the five that I have purchased for myself and family only one of them is still functional - and that's because my father quit drinking a year ago.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2016

title: Great while it lasted
content: So, why do I still give it three stars? Well, it's $20 and works well until it's inevitable failure. You'll very likely get between 1-2 years out of this guy (hopefully) and you won't regret your purchase once you use it... until you need to open wine and don't have an opener.. I've since moved on and now use the Onzeri one and have realized that this Oster model feels a lot more solid. The Ozeri sounds/feels like it's wheezing out its final breath whenever we use it to open wine. It has lasted longer, but it's feels like it has the motivation of a teenager being forced to do its chores whenever we use it. The saving grace for the Ozeri is that the charge is a cable that attaches to the outside and it doesn't rely on a base to do this, so even if it does with a cork in it we can still charge the opener and eject the cork.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2024
